article.title: Czes%C5%82aw_Mi%C5%82osz
article.paragraph: Czesaw Miosz(IPAc-plAUDPl-Czesław_Miłosz.ogg'czesłaf-'miłosz; 30 June 1911 14 August 2004) was aPolandPolishcite bookThe Oxford Companion to English LiteratureMargaretDrabble1985Oxford University PressOxford0-19-866130-4652cite bookLiteratura polska: przewodnik encyklopedyczny, Volume 1: A–MJulianKrzyżanowski1986Państwowe Wydawnictwo NaukoweWarszawa83-01-05368-2671–672poet,prosewriter,translatoranddiplomat. His World War II-era sequence,The World, is a collection of twenty "nave" poems. Following the war, he served as Polishcultural attachin Paris and Washington, D.C., then in 1951 defected to the West. His nonfiction book,The Captive Mind(1953), became a classic ofanti-Stalinism. From 1961 to 1998 he was a professor ofSlavic Languagesand Literatures at theUniversity of California, Berkeley. He became a U.S. citizen in 1970.In 1978 he was awarded theNeustadt International Prize for Literature, and in 1980 theNobel Prize in Literature. In 1999 he was named a Puterbaugh Fellow.cite webPuterbaugh Fellows {{!}} Puterbaugh Festival of International Literature & Culturehttp://puterbaughfestival.org/category/puterbaugh-fellows/#.Uxo-b3kqnbAWorld Literature Today7 March 2014After the fall of theIron Curtain, he divided his time betweenBerkeley, California, andKrakw,Poland.
article.heading: Life in Europe
article.paragraph: Czesaw Miosz was born on June 30, 1911, in the village of Szetejnie (lang-lt[[Šeteniai]]),Kovno Governorate,Russian Empire(nowKdainiai district municipalityKdainiai district,Kaunas County,Lithuania) on the border between two Lithuanian historical regions,SamogitiaandAuktaitija, in central Lithuania. As the son of Aleksander Miosz (d.1959), a Polish civil engineer ofLithuanianorigin.,"The Civic and the Tribal State: The State, Ethnicity, and the Multiethnic State" By Feliks Gross - Page 124cite bookSaulius SužiedėlisHistorical Dictionary of LithuaniaMiłosz often emphasized his Lithuanian origins1 February 2011Scarecrow Press978-0-8108-4914-3189cite bookIrena Grudzińska-GrossCzesław Miłosz and Joseph Brodsky: fellowship of poets...The "true" Poles reminded the nation of Milosz's Lithuanian origin, his religious unorthodoxy, and his leftist past24 November 2009Yale University Press978-0-300-14937-1291Encyclopedia of World Biography, Volume 11 - Page 40Robinson Jeffers, Dimensions of a poet - Page 177and Weronika,neKunat (1887-1945), descendant of the Syru noble family (she was a granddaughter ofSzymon Syru),cite bookBrusAnnaAnna Brus[[Polski Słownik Biograficzny]]462009Polska Akademia Nauk & Polska Akademia UmiejętnościSzymon Syruć314Miosz was fluent in Polish, Lithuanian, Russian, English, and French.cite newsCzeslaw Milosz, Poet and Nobelist Who Wrote of Modern Cruelties, Dies at 93http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?resMarch 17, 2008The New York TimesRaymond H.AndersonAugust 15, 2004His brother,Andrzej Miosz(19172002), a Polish journalist, translator of literature and of film subtitles into Polish, was a documentary-film producer who created Polish documentaries about his brother.

Miosz was raisedCatholic ChurchCatholicin rural Lithuania and emphasized his identity with the multi-ethnicGrand Duchy of Lithuania, a stance that led to ongoing controversies. He refused to categorically identify himself as either a Pole or a Lithuanian.cite webhttp://www.universityofcalifornia.edu/senate/inmemoriam/czeslawmilosz.htm [[University of California]]In MemoriamMiłosz would always place emphasis upon his identity as one of the last citizens of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania, a place of competing and overlapping identities. This stance—not Polish enough for some, not Lithuanian to others—would give rise to controversies that have not ceased with his death in either country.2008-03-17He said of himself: "I am a Lithuanian to whom it was not given to be a Lithuanian.",lt iconcite webIšėjus Česlovui Milošui, Lietuva neteko dalelės savęsMokslo Lietuva (Scientific Lithuania)lthttp://www.lms.lt/ML/200415/20041501.htmOctober 16, 2007and "My family in the sixteenth century already spoke Polish, just as many families in Finland spoke Swedish and in Ireland English, so I am a Polish not a Lithuanian poet. But the landscapes and perhaps the spirits of Lithuania have never abandoned me".Lost and found: the discovery of Lithuania in American fictionAura Paulauskien Rodopi 2007 page 24Miosz memorialised his Lithuanian childhood in a 1955 novel,The Issa Valley, and in the 1959 memoirNative Realm.cite newsCZESLAW MILOSZ 1911-2004[[San Francisco Chronicle]]http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?fileMarch 20, 2008RonaMarech15 August 2004He employed a Lithuanian-language tutor late in life to improve the skills acquired in his childhood. His explanation was that it might be the language spoken in heaven.cite bookCzeslaw MiloszSelected Poems: 1931-2004 (Biographical note)http://books.google.com/books?id18 September 20134 April 2006HarperCollins978-0-06-018867-2261He often is quoted as having said, "Language is the only homeland."

link.part: Czesaw Miosz ''(right)'' with brother Andrzej Miosz atPEN ClubWorld Congress, Warsaw, May 1999

article.paragraph: In his youth, Miosz came to adopt, as he put it, a "scientific, atheistic position mostly", although he was later to return to the Catholic faith.Haven, Cynthia L., "'A Sacred Vision': An Interview with Czesaw Miosz", in Haven, Cynthia L. (ed.),Czesaw Miosz: Conversations. University Press of Mississippi, 2006, p. 145.After graduation fromSigismund AugustusGymnasium (school)GymnasiuminVilnius, he studied law atVilnius UniversityStefan Batory Universityand in 1931 he travelled to Paris, where he was influenced by his distant cousinOscar Milosz, a French poet of Lithuanian descent and aSwedenborgian. In 1931, he formed the poetic group agary together with the young poets Jerzy Zagrski, Teodor Bujnicki, Aleksander Rymkiewicz, Jerzy Putrament and Jzef Maliski.Between Anxiety and Hope: The Poetry and Writing of Czeslaw Miloszby Edward Moejko. University of Alberta Press, 1988. pp 2f.Miosz's first volume of poetry was published in 1934. After receiving his law degree that year, he again spent a year in Paris on a fellowship. Upon returning, he worked as a commentator at Radio Wilno, but was dismissed, an action described as stemming from either his leftist views or for views overly sympathetic to Lithuania.cite news[[The Economist]]http://www.economist.com/node/31044072004-08-14Czeslaw Milosz, a Polish émigré poet, died on August 14th, aged 932011-04-06In pre-war Poland Mr Milosz felt stifled by the prevailing Catholic-nationalist ethos; he was sacked from a Polish radio station for being too pro-Lithuanian.Miosz wrote all his poetry, fiction and essays in Polish and translated the Old TestamentPsalmsinto Polish.

Miosz spent World War II inWarsaw, under Nazi Germany's "General Government". Here he attendedEducation in Poland during World War IIunderground lecturesby Polish philosopher and historian of philosophy andaestheticsWadysaw Tatarkiewicz. He did not join the PolishHome Army's resistance or participate in theWarsaw Uprising (1944)Warsaw Uprising, partly from an instinct for self-preservation and partly because he saw its leadership as right-wing and dictatorial.cite webhttp://www.drb.ie/essays/apples-at-world-s-endApples at World’s EndEnda O’Doherty[[Dublin Review of Books]]2014-06-05According to Irena Grudziska-Gross, he saw the uprising as a "doomed military effort" and lacked "patriotic elation"  he called it "a blameworthy, lightheaded enterprise."cite webhttp://aseees.org/newsnet/2012-08.pdfThe Year of Czesław MiłoszAugust 2012[[Association for Slavic, East European, and Eurasian Studies]]

After World War II, Miosz served as cultural attach of the newly formedPeople's Republic of PolandinParisand Washington D.C. For this he was criticized in some emigre circles. Conversely, he was attacked and censored in Poland when, in 1951, he defected and obtained political asylum in France. He described his life in Paris as difficult - there was still considerable intellectual sympathy for Communism.Albert Camuswas supportive butPablo Nerudadenounced him as "The Man Who Ran Away."cite bookCynthia L. HavenCzesław Miłosz: Conversationshttp://books.google.com/books?id2006Univ. Press of Mississippi978-1-57806-829-6206His attempts to seek asylum in the US were denied for several years, due to the climate ofMcCarthyism.cite bookEric Thomas ChesterCovert Network: Progressives, the International Rescue Committee, and the CIAhttp://books.google.com/books?id26 June 1995M.E. Sharpe978-0-7656-3495-572–73

Miosz's 1953 book,The Captive Mind, is a study about howintellectualsbehave under a repressive regime. Miosz observed that those who becamedissidentswere not necessarily those with the strongest minds, but rather those with the weakest stomachs; the mind can rationalize anything, he said, but the stomach can take only so much. Throughout theCold War, the book was often cited by U.S. conservative commentators such asWilliam F. Buckley, Jr., and it has been a staple in political science courses ontotalitarianism.
In 1953 he received the Prix Littraire Europen (European Literary Prize).
article.heading: Righteous Among the Nations
article.paragraph: During theNazi occupation of Poland, Miosz was active in the work of Organizacja Socjalistyczno-Niepodlegociowa "Wolno" ("The 'Freedom' Socialist Pro-Independence Organisation"). In his activity with "Wolno", Miosz gave aid toWarsawJews. His brotherAndrzej Mioszwas alsoRescue of Jews by Poles during the Holocaustactive in helping Jews in Nazi-occupied Poland, and in 1943 Andrzej transported the Polish Jew Seweryn Tross and his wife fromVilniusto Warsaw. Czesaw Miosz took in the Trosses and found them a hiding place and supported them financially. The Trosses ultimately died during theWarsaw Uprising. Miosz helped at least three other Jews, Felicja Wokomiska and her brother and sister. For these efforts, Miosz received the medal of theRighteous Among the NationsinYad Vashem,Israelin 1989.Czesaw Mioszhis activity to save Jews' lives during theHolocaust, atYad Vashemwebsitecite webhttp://teatrnn.pl/leksykon/node/3219/czes%C5%82aw_mi%C5%82osz_1911%E2%80%932004#12Czesław Miłosz (1911-2011)[Leksykon Lublin]
article.heading: Life in the United States
article.paragraph: File:Czesaw Miosz 1986 (2).jpgthumbright200pxMiosz, 1998In 1960 Miosz emigrated to the United States, and in 1970 he became a U.S. citizen. In 1961 he began a professorship in the Department ofSlavic Languagesand Literatures at theUniversity of California, Berkeley.cite webhttp://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/literature/laureates/1980/milosz-bio.htmlCzeslaw Milosz - Biographicalnobelprize.org (Nobel Prize Media)2014-06-04

In 1978 he received theNeustadt International Prize for Literature.He retired the same year but continued teaching at Berkeley. His attitude about living in Berkeley is sensitively portrayed in his poem, "A Magic Mountain," contained in a collection of translated poems,Bells in Winter(Ecco Press, 1985).

In 1980 Miosz received theNobel Prize in Literature. Since his works had been banned in Poland by the communist government, this was the first time that many Poles became aware of him.Citation neededFebruary 2008After theIron Curtainfell, he was able to return to Poland, at first to visit, later to live part-time inKrakw. He divided his time between his home in Berkeley and an apartment in Krakw.

In 1977 he had been given an honorary doctorate by theUniversity of Michigan; two weeks after he received the 1980 Nobel Prize in Literature, he returned to Michigan to lecture, and in 1983 he became the Visiting Walgreen Professor of Human Understanding. In 1989 he received the U.S.National Medal of Artsand an honorary doctorate fromHarvard University.

In a 1994 interview, Miosz spoke of the difficulty of writing religious poetry in a largely post-religious world. He reported a recent conversation with his compatriotPope John Paul II; the latter, commenting upon some of Miosz's work, in particularSix Lectures in Verse, said to him: "You make one step forward, one step back." The poet answered: "Holy Father, how in the twentieth century can one write religious poetry differently?" The Pope smiled."Czesaw Miosz Interviewed by Robert Faggen",The Paris ReviewNo. 133 (Winter 1994).A few years later, in 2000, Miosz dedicated a rather straightforward ode to John Paul II, on the occasion of the pope's eightieth birthday.Andreas Dorschel, 'Es ist eine Lust zu beichten',Sddeutsche Zeitungnr. 192 (20 August 2004), p. 14.
article.heading: Death and legacy
article.paragraph: File:2007PolskaSkaka.jpgthumb250pxMiosz's final resting place:SkakaSkaka Roman Catholic Church,KrakwCzesaw Miosz died on 14 August 2004 at his Krakw home, aged 93. He was buried inKrakw'sSkakaSkaka Roman Catholic Church, becoming one of the last to be commemorated there.Photos from Miosz's funeral in KrakowProtesters threatened to disrupt the proceedings on the grounds that he was anti-Polish, anti-Catholic, and had signed a petition supporting gay and lesbian freedom of speech and assembly.cite webhttp://www.booksandculture.com/articles/webexclusives/2004/september/040907.htmlThe Poet Who Remembered - Poland (mostly) honors Czeslaw Miłosz upon his deathAgnieszka Tennantbooksandculture.comPopeJohn Paul II, along with Miosz's confessor, issued public messages to the effect that Miosz had been receiving the sacraments, which quelled the protest.cite bookIrena Grudzińska-GrossCzeslaw Milosz and Joseph Brodskyhttp://books.google.com/books?id18 September 20132009Yale University Press978-0-300-14937-1289

His first wife, Janina (ne Duska, b. 1909), whom he had married in 1944, had died in 1986; they had two sons, Anthony (b. 1947) and John Peter (b. 1951). His second wife, Carol Thigpen (b. 1944), an American-born historian, had died in 2002.

Miosz is honoured at Israel'sYad Vashemmemorial to theThe HolocaustHolocaust, as one of the "Righteous among the Nations". A poem by Miosz appears on aGdaskMonument to the Fallen Shipyard Workers of 1970memorial to protesting shipyard workerswho had been killed by government security forces in 1970. His books and poems have been translated by many hands, including Jane Zielonko,Peter Dale Scott,Robert Pinsky, andRobert Hass.

In November 2011, Yale University hosted a conference on Miosz's relationship with America.conference on Miosz and AmericaTheBeinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, which holds the Czesaw Miosz Papers,Czesaw Miosz Papersalso hosted an exhibition celebrating Miosz's life and work, entitledExile as Destiny: Czeslaw Miosz and America. 2011 was deemed "The Miosz Year," which culminated in a large conference in Krakw (May 915, 2011).
